intro: Melampodium digynum, commonly known as the two-flowered sunflower, is a herbaceous perennial native to the southeastern United States. It features bright yellow flowers with a distinctive red center, typically blooming from late spring to early fall. The plant has opposite, lance-shaped leaves with hairy surfaces and produces small, capsule-like fruits that contain numerous seeds. It thrives in full sun and well-drained soil, often found in open woodlands and prairies. Its botanical characteristics make it a valuable addition to native plant gardens and ecological restoration projects.
